entry.title: dragonesque brooch (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that if the double-headed Romano-British dragonesque brooch type (example pictured) represents any real animal, it may be hares rather than dragons?

entry.title: Adeeb Youssef (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that human rights activist Adeeb Youssef was imprisoned and tortured but later became the governor of Central Darfur?

entry.title: Cross Temple (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Cross Temple in Fangshan, Beijing, is the only surviving Nestorian Christian site in China?

entry.title: Switch Disco (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Switch Disco's song "Everything" saw a 185-percent increase in its Spotify streams after it was used in the seventh series of Love Island?

entry.title: rizz (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that after popularizing the term rizz, Kai Cenat stopped using the term himself, saying that TikTok had butchered the word?

entry.title: Jetson One (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Forbes said of the Jetson One aircraft, "Flying Cars Are Here"?

entry.title: E. S. Brusky (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that after accepting the job of team physician for the Green Bay Packers in 1962, E. S. Brusky was not paid a salary for at least the first nine years of his tenure?

entry.title: artificial planets (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that examples of artificial planets in science fiction include Riverworld, the Well World, and the Death Star?
